importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news article indicates the most recent update on the flooding crisis, reflecting the ongoing humanitarian and governmental response efforts in Mexico.
The date of the rainfall and flooding (implied to be the week prior) is critical for understanding the timing and severity of the disaster, with peak rainfall reported on Wednesday.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding occurred over a week, culminating in the reported death toll and missing persons, illustrating the prolonged and evolving nature of the disaster.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding across five states.
The state of Veracruz reported 29 deaths, Hidalgo 21, Puebla 13, and Queretaro 1.
Another 65 people are still missing, with 43 in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rise and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall was recorded in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain, respectively.
Thousands of military troops from the Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard have been deployed to assist, distributing food and clean water.
Over 100,000 homes have been affected, with some near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
Nearly 400 repair workers restored over 80% of the electricity supply for about 263,000 affected users.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported the death and missing figures during President Claudia Sheinbaum’s daily briefing.
President Claudia Sheinbaum acknowledged that there were no clear meteorological signs indicating such extreme rainfall, raising questions about Mexico’s early warning systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond caused widespread flooding and landslides across five Mexican states, resulting in 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The hardest-hit areas were Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), and Puebla (13 deaths). The National Civil Protection Coordination reported that over 100,000 homes were affected, with some near rivers completely destroyed. Military forces including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard mobilized to deliver food, water, and medical aid, while nearly 400 repair workers restored over 80% of the electricity supply for around 263,000 affected users. Despite extensive response efforts, officials acknowledged a lack of early warning signs, raising concerns about the effectiveness of Mexico’s meteorological alert systems.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
